question: [File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: OIDCProvider::new()] [Input validation bypass] Can an attacker craft malicious OIDC provider entries with extremely long name/config_url strings (e.g., GBs of data) that bypass size limits, causing memory exhaustion and DoS when validators load OnChainConfig? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: OIDCProvider::new()] [URL injection] Can an attacker inject malicious URLs in config_url field (e.g., localhost, internal IPs, file://) that validators automatically fetch, enabling SSRF attacks against validator infrastructure? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: OIDCProvider::try_from()] [UTF-8 validation bypass] Does the UTF-8 conversion at lines 88-89 properly validate multi-byte sequences, or can an attacker insert invalid UTF-8 to cause panics or bypass string validation logic? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: OIDCProvider::from()] [Data truncation] In the From implementation at lines 74-81, can an attacker exploit non-UTF-8 bytes in the source that get silently dropped during .as_bytes().to_vec(), creating inconsistent provider identities? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: OIDCProvider::try_from()] [Error handling bypass] If String::from_utf8() fails at line 88, does error propagation prevent state corruption, or can partial conversion leave the system in an inconsistent state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Struct: OIDCProvider] [Unicode normalization] Can an attacker register two OIDC providers with visually identical but different Unicode representations (e.g., combining characters) to bypass uniqueness checks and register duplicate providers? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: dummy_issuer()] [Test code in production] The dummy_issuer() function at line 54 contains a typo 'https:://' - can this test function be called in production to register invalid issuers that bypass URL validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: issuer_from_str()] [Null byte injection] Can an attacker inject null bytes in issuer strings at line 49 that get preserved in Vec<u8> but cause string comparison mismatches in downstream code? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Struct: SupportedOIDCProviders] [Unbounded vector] The providers Vec at line 106 has no size limit - can an attacker add unlimited providers through governance, causing memory exhaustion when validators load this OnChainConfig? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: SupportedOIDCProviders::into_provider_vec()] [Move semantics] Does into_provider_vec() at line 110 safely transfer ownership, or can double-consumption bugs lead to use-after-free in the Move VM? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [OnChainConfig: SupportedOIDCProviders] [MODULE_IDENTIFIER injection] Can an attacker manipulate the MODULE_IDENTIFIER at line 116 through a malicious Move module to hijack config loading and inject arbitrary provider lists? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKs::indexed()] [HashMap collision DoS] At lines 140-145, if multiple JWKs hash to the same id(), does HashMap::insert() silently overwrite entries, allowing an attacker to eclipse legitimate keys? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKs::indexed()] [Integer overflow] Can the conversion loop at lines 141-144 cause stack overflow if self.jwks contains millions of entries, crashing validator nodes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKs::new()] [Version initialization] ProviderJWKs::new() initializes version to 0 at line 134 - can an attacker exploit version rollback by creating new ProviderJWKs that override existing ones with higher versions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Struct: ProviderJWKs] [Version monotonicity] Is version field at line 126 enforced to be monotonically increasing, or can an attacker submit updates with decreasing versions to rollback to compromised JWKs? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKs::get_jwk()] [Linear search DoS] The get_jwk() method at lines 169-186 uses linear iteration - can an attacker add thousands of JWKs to make key lookups extremely slow, DoSing keyless transaction validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKs::get_jwk()] [Type confusion] In the JWK::try_from() conversion at line 171, can an attacker craft malformed JWKMoveStruct that passes initial checks but causes panics in RSA vs Unsupported matching? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKs::get_jwk()] [Case sensitivity] Key ID comparison at lines 174 and 179 uses .eq() - can an attacker bypass lookups using case variations of the kid field that validate but don't match? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKs::get_jwk()] [Error message leak] The error at line 185 reveals the searched key ID - can this leak sensitive information about failed authentication attempts to network observers? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Derive: CryptoHasher] [Hash collision] ProviderJWKs derives CryptoHasher at line 122 - can an attacker craft two different ProviderJWKs with identical BCS hashes to bypass signature verification in QuorumCertifiedUpdate? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Field: issuer] [Serde bytes annotation] The issuer field uses serde_bytes at line 124 - can this annotation be exploited to inject non-UTF8 bytes that bypass subsequent string validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Struct: ProviderJWKs] [Clone implementation] ProviderJWKs derives Clone at line 122 - if jwks Vec contains GBs of data, can excessive cloning in hot paths cause memory exhaustion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKs::as_move_value()] [Move serialization] Does as_move_value() at lines 189-196 properly validate vector lengths, or can oversized jwks vectors crash the Move VM during deserialization? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Struct: ProviderJWKsIndexed] [Unvalidated HashMap] ProviderJWKsIndexed stores JWKs in HashMap at line 204 without validation - can an attacker insert malicious JWKs directly into the map bypassing ProviderJWKs::indexed() checks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/jwks/mod.rs] [Function: ProviderJWKsIndexed::new()] [Inconsistent initialization] new() creates empty HashMap at line 212 but doesn't validate issuer - can mismatched issuer/jwks state cause authentication bypass? (High)
